<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>1,695</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>1,618</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>1,707</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>2,385</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>2,387</B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Of the total borrowings of
&pound;1,618&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;2,385 million), &pound;268&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;1,190 million) were borrowings due within one year and &pound;1,350&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;1,195 million) were borrowings due after one year.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">At year end the book value of assets pledged as collateral for secured loans was &pound;nil million (2008: &pound;nil million). </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The fair values in the table above are quoted market prices or, if not available, values estimated by discounting future cash flows to net present value. For
short-term borrowings with a maturity of less than one year the book values approximate to the fair values because of their short term nature. For non public long-term loans, fair values are estimated by discounting future contractual cash flows to
net present values using current market interest rates available to the Group for similar financial instruments as at year end. The table contains fair values of debt instruments based on clean prices, which exclude accrued interest. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Notes listed above are issued out of the Group&#146;s US Debt Programme and Euro Medium Term Note Programme. Both programmes are subject to standard debt
covenants requiring all debt to be ranked pari passu. Both Programmes contain customary negative pledge and cross default clauses. The Group is currently in compliance with these requirements. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The 5.125% USD Notes due 2013 are callable at the issuer&#146;s option. These Notes are redeemable at the higher of 100% of the face value of the Notes or the net
present value of the remaining cash flows using a discount factor comprised of the US Treasury rate plus 25 basis points respectively. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The interest
rates on the Notes in the above table do not take into account the various interest rate swaps and cross currency swaps entered into by the Group. Details of the Group&#146;s currency and interest rate risk management instruments are contained
below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group&#146;s borrowing limit at 31&nbsp;December 2009 calculated in accordance with the Articles of Association was
&pound;12,924&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;12,975 million). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Committed Facilities </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">In 2009 the Group entered into a &pound;450&nbsp;million Revolving Credit Facility (dated 30&nbsp;June 2009) that matures in 26&nbsp;June 2012. The facility
replaced the existing &pound;1 billion Revolving Credit Facility which was due to expire in March 2010. The Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn as at 31&nbsp;December 2009. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>55 </B></FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Financial statements </B>continued<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>27. Borrowings and Financial Instruments</B> (continued)<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Interest on bank loans is at rates which vary in accordance with local inter-bank rates. The amount of
non-interest bearing loans is negligible. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(b) Financial instruments &#150; derivatives </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The fair value of interest rate and currency derivative assets was &pound;88&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;268 million). The fair value of interest rate and currency
derivative liabilities was &pound;97&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;169 million) of which &pound;3&nbsp;million is classified as non-current (2008: &pound;nil) relating to the fair value hedge as discussed below. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The fair values of derivative instruments are based on the estimated amount the Group would receive or pay if the transaction was terminated. For currency and
interest rate derivatives, fair values are calculated using standard market calculation conventions with reference to the relevant closing market spot rates. In terms of the fair value hierarchy interest rate and currency derivatives are classified
as level 2 financial instruments (i.e. based on a pricing model that has significant observable inputs) commodity derivatives are classified as a combination of level 1 (i.e. fair values are quoted market prices for identical assets and liabilities)
and level 2 financial instruments. The Group has no financial instruments which are classified as level 3 (i.e. based on a pricing model that has significant unobservable inputs). </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Interest rate derivatives </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group uses interest rate
swaps to manage the interest rate profile of its borrowings. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">As at 31&nbsp;December 2009 the Group had a &pound;100&nbsp;million interest rate swap
receiving fixed interest at 4.875% and paying floating interest based on 6 month Sterling LIBOR rates. The swap matures in December 2010. The Group also had interest rate swaps, maturing in July 2018 with a nominal value of &pound;350&nbsp;million
that received interest at 7.25% and paid interest based on 6 month Sterling LIBOR rates. Such swaps were closed out using a combination of forward rate agreements and forward starting interest rate swaps effective February 2010. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">As at 31&nbsp;December 2008 the Group had a
<FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#128;</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"></FONT>100&nbsp;million interest rate swap paying interest at a fixed rate of 3.64% and receiving interest based on 6 month Euro LIBOR rates.
The swap matured in January 2009. The Group had a &pound;100&nbsp;million interest rate swap receiving fixed interest at 4.875% and paying floating interest based on 6 month Sterling LIBOR rates. The swap matures in August 2010. Finally, the Group
had interest rate swaps, maturing in July 2018 with a nominal value of &pound;350&nbsp;million that receive interest at 7.25% and pay interest based on 6 month Sterling LIBOR rates. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Fair value hedges </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">In addition to the above as at
31&nbsp;December 2009 the Group had a &pound;300m interest rate swap paying interest based on 6 month Sterling LIBOR rates and receiving 5.375%. The swap matures in December 2014. This interest rate swap is designated and is effective as a fair
value hedge in respect of interest rate risk on the 5.375% Sterling 300m note. During the period the hedge was 94% effective in hedging the fair value exposure to interest rate movements and as a result the carrying value of the loan was adjusted by
a &pound;3m gain which was included in the profit and loss at the same time that the fair value loss of &pound;3m on the interest rate swap was included in profit and loss. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Currency derivatives </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group uses currency forwards and
swaps to manage the currency profile of its borrowings net of cash and short-term investments. The table below shows the Group&#146;s currency profile of borrowings as at 31&nbsp;December 2009 after taking into consideration currency forwards and
swaps. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>56 </B></FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">1,837</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group also uses currency forwards, swaps and options
based derivatives to manage its transactional exposures arising from its international trade. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Embedded derivatives </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group has reviewed all contracts for embedded derivatives that are required to be separately accounted for if they do not meet certain requirements set out in
IAS 39. As at 31&nbsp;December 2009, the fair value of embedded derivatives was a liability of &pound;1&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;1 million). This relates to foreign exchange forward contracts embedded within certain procurement contracts that
mature within two years. Amounts recorded in the income statement are included within those disclosed in Note 10 to the financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(c)
Financial instruments &#150; assets </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash held by the Group whilst short-term investments held by the Group are in
the form of bank deposits and money market fund deposits. The carrying amount of these assets approximates to their fair value. Cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments are categorised as loans and receivables under IAS 39. At year end,
there was &pound;181&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;118 million) cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments held by subsidiary companies that carry a cost of repatriation. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(d) Contractual obligations </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Net settled </B></FONT></P>

are financial assets, future contractual obligations are not shown. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Estimated future interest rate payments on borrowings are based on the applicable
fixed and floating rates of interest as at the end of the year for all borrowings or interest rate swap liabilities. The interest obligations in the above table have been calculated assuming that all borrowings and swaps in existence at year end
will be held to maturity and are on a constant currency basis. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>28. Treasury Risk Management </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Other than expressly stated, the policies set out below also apply to prior years, and the information provided is representative of the Group&#146;s exposure to
risk during the period. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>58 </B></FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Financial statements </B>continued<B> </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>28. Treasury Risk Management </B>(continued)<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(a) Credit Risk </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group is exposed to credit related losses in the event of non-performance by counterparties to financial instruments, but it does not expect any counterparties
to fail to meet their obligations given the Group&#146;s policy of selecting only counterparties with high credit ratings. The exposure to credit loss of liquid assets is equivalent to the carrying value on the balance sheet. The maximum credit
exposure of interest rate and foreign exchange derivative contracts is represented by the fair value of contracts with a positive fair value at the reporting date. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Counterparties to financial instruments are limited to financial institutions with high credit ratings assigned by international credit rating agencies. The Group
has ISDA Master Agreements with all of its counterparties to financial derivatives, which permits net settlement of assets and liabilities in certain circumstances, thereby reducing the Group&#146;s credit exposure to individual counterparties. The
Group has policies that limit the amount of credit exposure to any single financial institution. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Concentrations of credit risk with respect to trade
receivables are limited due to the Group&#146;s customer base being large and unrelated. There were no significant concentrations of credit exposure at the year-end relating to other aspects of credit. Management therefore believe there is no
further credit risk provision required in excess of normal provision for doubtful receivables. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group is exposed to &pound;1,501&nbsp;million in
credit exposure on financial guarantees issued in respect of Group corporate borrowings and certain subsidiary undertakings which represents the Group&#146;s maximum credit exposure arising from guarantees. Refer to Note 34 on Commitments and
Contingencies for further details. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The financial assets of the Group which are exposed to credit risk are: </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="76%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">108</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Commodities</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>3</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&#151;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(b) Liquidity Risk </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group is exposed to liquidity risk due to the possibility that un-forecast situations could give rise to uncertainty amongst lenders resulting in unavailability
of uncommitted sources of funds. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group seeks to achieve a balance between certainty of funding, even at difficult times for the markets or the
Group, and a flexible, cost-effective borrowings structure. Consequently the policy seeks to ensure that all projected net borrowing needs are covered by committed facilities. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The objective for debt maturities is to ensure that the amount of debt maturing in any one year is not beyond the Group&#146;s means to repay and refinance. To
this end the policy provides that at least 75% of year-end net debt should have a maturity of one year or more and at least 50%, three years or more. Committed but undrawn facilities may be taken into account for these tests. At year end the Group
was in compliance with this policy. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Company manages the liquidity risk inherent in this analysis by having diverse funding sources and committed
borrowing facilities that can be accessed to meet liquidity needs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>59 </B></FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Financial statements </B>continued<B> </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>28. Treasury Risk Management </B>(continued) </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(c) Market Risk </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(i) Currency Risk </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group operates internationally giving
rise to exposure from changes in foreign exchange rates. The Group does not hedge translation exposure and earnings because any benefit obtained from such hedging can only be temporary. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group seeks to relate the structure of borrowings to the trading cash flows that service them. This is achieved by raising funds in different currencies and
through the use of hedging instruments such as swaps. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group also has transactional currency exposures arising from its international trade. The
Group&#146;s policy is to take forward cover for forecasted receipts and payments for as far ahead as the pricing structures are committed. The Group makes use of the forward foreign exchange markets to hedge its exposures. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">While there are exchange control restrictions which affect the ability of certain of the Group&#146;s subsidiaries to transfer funds to the Group, the operations
affected by such restrictions are not material to the Group as a whole and the Group does not believe such restrictions have had or will have any material adverse impact on the Group as a whole or the ability of the Group to meet its cash flow
requirements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(ii) Interest Rate Risk </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group
has an exposure to interest rate fluctuations on its borrowings and cash and short-term investments and manages these by the use of interest rate swaps, cross currency interest rate swaps and forward rate agreements. The objectives for the mix
between fixed and floating rate borrowings are set to reduce the impact of an upward change in interest rates while enabling benefits to be enjoyed if interest rates fall. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The treasury risk management policy sets minimum and maximum target levels of the total of net debt and preferred securities permitted to be at fixed or capped
rates in various time bands, ranging from 50% to 100% for the period up to six months, to 0% to 30% when over five years. These percentages are measured with reference to the current level of net debt. 69% of net debt was at fixed rates of interest
at year end (2008: 71%). The Group was in compliance with policy at year end. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(iii) Fair value analysis </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The table below presents a fair value analysis and a sensitivity analysis of the impact on the Income Statement from hypothetical changes in market rates. The fair
values are quoted market prices for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1) or, if not available, values derived from market prices (Level 2), which are determined by discounting future cash flows to net present values. The Group has no financial
instruments which are fair valued based on a pricing model with significant unobservable inputs (Level 3). For currency and interest rate derivatives, fair values are calculated using standard market calculation conventions with reference to the
relevant closing market spot rates. For cash and cash equivalents, short term investments, trade and other receivables, trade and other payables and short-term loans and receivables with a maturity of less than one year the book values approximate
to the fair values because of their short- term nature. For non- public long-term loans and receivables, fair values are estimated by discounting future contractual cash flows to net present values using current market interest rates available to
the Group for similar financial instruments as at year end. The table contains fair values of debt instruments based on clean prices excluding accrued interest. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The table below shows a sensitivity analysis of market risk assuming certain adverse market conditions occur. The sensitivity figures are calculated based on a
downward parallel shift of 1% in yield curves and 20% weakening of sterling against other exchange rates. An upward parallel shift of 1% in yield curves and 20% strengthening of sterling against other exchange rates would result in an equal and
opposite effect on fair values to the table below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">This is a method of analysis used to assess and mitigate risk and should not be considered a
projection of likely future events and losses. Actual results and market conditions in the future may be materially different from those projected and changes in the instruments held and in the financial markets in which we operate could cause
losses to exceed the amounts projected. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>60 </B></FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Financial statements </B>continued<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>28. Treasury Risk Management</B> (continued)<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>As at 31&nbsp;December 2009: </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="84%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="63%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="9%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="9%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">1</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1">The Group hedges against currency risk using currency derivative contracts and by structuring the currency of its borrowings to relate to the trading cash flows
that service them. Where IAS 39 hedge accounting is not applied the offsetting effect of such hedges is not included in the tables above. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">2</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1">Represented for the reclassification of &pound;139&nbsp;million from short-term investments to cash and cash equivalents as described in note 1(s).
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(iv) Commodities </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">In respect
of commodities the Group enters into derivative contracts for cocoa, sugar and other commodities in order to provide a stable cost base for marketing finished products. The use of commodity derivative contracts enables the Group to obtain the
benefit of guaranteed contract performance on firm priced contracts offered by banks, the exchanges and their clearing houses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The continuing group
held the following commodity futures contracts at 31&nbsp;December 2009: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="76%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="86%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>

<TD></TD>

<TD ROWSPAN="2" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ROWSPAN="2" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2009</B></FONT><br><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>Fair</B></FONT><br><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1">
<B>value</B></FONT><br><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>&pound;m</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ROWSPAN="2" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008</B></FONT><br><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>Fair</B></FONT><br><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1">

<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Commodities asset</FONT></P></TD>

<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>)&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Financial statements </B>continued<B> </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>28. Treasury Risk Management</B> (continued)<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The commodities derivative contracts held by the Group at the year-end expose the Group to adverse movements in
cash flow and gains or losses due to the market risk arising from changes in prices for sugar, cocoa and other commodity derivatives. Applying a reasonable rise or fall in commodity prices (between 8% and 13% (2008: between 6% and 10%)) to the
Group&#146;s net commodity positions held at the year end would result in a movement of &pound;6&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;9 million) which would be recognised in the finance charge for the period. The price sensitivity applied in this case is
estimated based on an absolute average of historical monthly changes in prices in the Group&#146;s commodities over a two year period. Stocks, priced forward contracts and estimated anticipated purchases are not included in the calculations of the
sensitivity analysis. This method of analysis is used to assess and mitigate risk and should not be considered a projection of likely future events and losses. Actual results and market conditions in the future may be materially different from those
projected and changed in the instruments held and in the financial markets in which we operate could cause losses to exceed the amounts projected. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>29. Share Capital </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(a) Share capital of Cadbury plc </B>

right to fixed income. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">During 2009, 12,501,108 ordinary shares of 10p in Cadbury plc were allotted and issued upon the exercise of share options, with
a nominal value of &pound;1.3 million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">On 11&nbsp;April 2008 shareholders in Cadbury Schweppes plc approved a special resolution and a Scheme of
Arrangement and on 2&nbsp;May 2008, a new holding company, Cadbury plc was inserted into the Group over the listed parent company, Cadbury Schweppes plc, and on that date the ordinary shares of Cadbury plc were admitted to listing on The London and
New York Stock Exchanges (as ADRs in the case of New York), the shares and ADRs of Cadbury Schweppes plc being delisted at the same time. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The issued
capital of Cadbury plc on 7&nbsp;May 2008, after the reduction of capital, was &pound;135,299,057.40 divided into 1,352,990,574 ordinary shares of 10p each. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">During the period from 7&nbsp;May 2008 to 31&nbsp;December 2008, 7,781,332 ordinary shares of 10p in Cadbury plc were allotted and issued upon the exercise of
share options with a nominal value of &pound;0.8 million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">During the period from 1&nbsp;January 2008 to 7&nbsp;May 2008, 4,939,337 ordinary shares of
12.5p in Cadbury Schweppes plc, the previous parent company of the Group, were allotted and issued upon the exercise of share options, with a nominal value of &pound;0.6 million. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(b) Nature of reserves </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">At 31&nbsp;December 2009, the Group
held 2&nbsp;million (2008: 10 million) of own shares purchased by the Cadbury Employee Trust for use in employee share plans. During 2009, an additional &pound;22&nbsp;million of the Company&#146;s shares were purchased by the Trust (2008: &pound;47
million). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">During 2009, the Company received &pound;60&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;38 million) on the issue of shares in respect of the exercise of
options awarded under various share option plans. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The capital redemption reserve arose on the redemption of preference shares in 1997. </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">At 31&nbsp;December 2009 the hedging and translation reserve comprises &pound;245&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;443
million) relating to all foreign exchange differences arising from the translation of the financial statements of foreign operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The acquisition
revaluation reserve arose on the step acquisition of former associates to subsidiaries in 2006. It represents the increase in the fair value of assets acquired attributable to the previously owned share. These subsidiaries were demerged during 2008.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The demerger reserve arose in 2008 on demerger of the Americas Beverages business and the associated Scheme of Arrangement whereby Cadbury plc was
inserted into the Group over the listed parent company, Cadbury Schweppes plc. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>30. Minority interests </B></FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>20</B></FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>12</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B></B>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">All minority interests are equity in
nature. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The increase in the group&#146;s shareholding of &pound;9&nbsp;million relates primarily to: </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">- In December 2009, Cadbury Nigeria carried out a rights issue which increased the Group&#146;s shareholding to 75%. As a result of the rights issue the group
received cash of &pound;8&nbsp;million from minority interests. The subscription of this rights issue led to Cadbury Nigeria being in a net asset position as at 31&nbsp;December 2009. The minority share of the net assets increased by
&pound;12&nbsp;million, after allocating &pound;7&nbsp;million of losses which had not been allocated in previous years when Cadbury Nigeria was in a net liability position. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">- In May 2009 the Group increased its holding in Kent Gida Maddeleri to 99.36 percent, reducing the minority interest by &pound;3 million. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">As at 31&nbsp;December 2009, Cadbury Fourseas is in a net liabilities position. The minority interests have no contractual obligation to meet these liabilities,
consequently no minority interest asset has been recognised. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>31. Acquisitions </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>2009 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group made no acquisitions in 2009. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>2008 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group made no acquisitions in 2008. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">In 2008, the Group recorded adjustments to the opening balance sheet of Intergum, a Turkish confectionery company acquired on 31&nbsp;August 2007 for initial
consideration of &pound;192 million. These adjustments are principally a reduction in consideration of &pound;22&nbsp;million relating to the finalisation of the purchase price and a reduction of &pound;13&nbsp;million in net assets reflecting the
finalisation of property, plant and equipment fair values, which have caused the goodwill on acquisition to decrease by &pound;9 million. In addition, the Group has recorded adjustments to the opening balance sheet of Kandia-Excelent which has
increased goodwill by &pound;1 million. The Group also paid a further &pound;6&nbsp;million during 2008 relating to additional acquisition costs of businesses acquired in 2007 of which &pound;3&nbsp;million had been accrued in 2007. The net impact
of all adjustments made in 2008 relating to 2007 acquisitions is summarised below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>63 </B></FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Intangible assets</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">(3</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">)&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Property, plant and equipment</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">(12</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="top" NOWRAP> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Adjustment to consideration paid net of unaccrued transaction costs</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(19</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>)</B>&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>32. Discontinued operations
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">On 3&nbsp;April 2009, the Group completed the disposal of its Australia Beverages business and on 7&nbsp;May 2008, the Group completed the demerger
of its Americas Beverages business. In accordance with IFRS 5, &#147;Non-current assets held for sale and discontinued operations&#148; these businesses are classified as discontinued and the prior periods have been re-presented on a consistent
basis. The re-presentation includes an allocation of the Group&#146;s interest charge relating to the debt funding which was demerged with the Americas Beverage business. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(a) The results of the discontinued operations, which have been included in the consolidated income statement, are as follows: </B></FONT></P>

<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>)&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">130</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Taxation from discontinued operations including tax on demerger costs</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(88</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>)&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(28</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>)&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">UK tax is calculated at 28% (2008: 28.5%)
of the estimated assessable profit for the year. Taxation for other jurisdictions is calculated at the rates prevailing in the respective jurisdictions. The current year tax charge primarily represents tax in relation to the disposal of Australia
Beverages. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">No reconciliation of the tax rate for discontinued operations has been provided given the discrete nature of the balances. </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">1</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1">Effect of tax on above items includes a charge of &pound;88&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;44&nbsp;million credit) relating to the disposal of Australia Beverages.

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">2</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1">Includes &pound;nil (2008: &pound;18 million) of non-underlying finance costs associated with the demerger. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">It is the Group&#146;s policy to lease certain of its plant and equipment under finance leases. Interest rates are fixed at
the contract date. All leases are on a fixed repayment basis and no arrangements are entered into for contingent rental payments. The carrying value of the Group&#146;s lease obligations approximates their fair value. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>(b) Operating leases </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-right:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">At the balance sheet
date, the Group had outstanding commitments for future minimum lease payments&nbsp;under&nbsp;non-cancellable&nbsp;operating leases, which fall due as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Holdings Limited, a subsidiary of the Company, has guaranteed borrowings and other liabilities of certain subsidiary undertakings, the amounts outstanding and recognised
on the Group balance sheet at 31&nbsp;December 2009 being &pound;1,501&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;2,185 million). In addition, certain of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries have guaranteed borrowings of certain other subsidiaries. The amount covered by
such arrangements as at 31&nbsp;December 2009 was &pound;1,432million (2008: &pound;1,693 million). Payment under these guarantees would be required in the event that the relevant subsidiary was unable to pay the guaranteed borrowings when due.
These guarantees cover the Group&#146;s borrowings of &pound;1,618&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;2,385 million) and have the same maturity. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">(b)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Subsidiary undertakings have guarantees and indemnities outstanding amounting to &pound;35&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;18 million). </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">(c)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Group has given a number of indemnities on certain disposals including the demerger of the Americas Beverages business as to the ownership of assets and intellectual
property, all outstanding tax liabilities, environmental liabilities and product liability claims. These may expire over a period of time up to the local statute of limitations although for ownership of assets and intellectual property these may be
indefinite. Where appropriate the Group has made provisions for any liabilities which may crystallise. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>68 </B></FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Financial statements </B>continued<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>34. Contingent liabilities and financial commitments </B>(continued)<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">(d)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Credit risk represents the accounting loss that would be recognised at the reporting date if counterparties failed completely to perform as contracted. Concentrations of credit
risk (whether on or off balance sheet) that arise from financial instruments exist for groups of customers or counterparties when they have similar economic characteristics that would cause their ability to meet contractual obligations to be
similarly affected by changes in economic or other conditions. The Group does not have a significant exposure to any individual customer, counterparty, or to any geographical region. The Group conducts business with banks representing many
nationalities, in most cases through offices and branches located in London and maintains strict limits over its exposure to any individual counterparty. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Group companies are defendants in a number of legal and taxation proceedings incidental to their operations. The Group does not expect that the outcome of such proceedings either
individually or in the aggregate will have a material effect on the Group&#146;s operations, cash flows or financial position. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>35.

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Financial statements </B>continued<B> </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>37. Related party transactions </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Transactions between the Company and its subsidiaries, which are related parties, have been eliminated on consolidation and are not disclosed in this note.
Transactions between the Group and its associates are disclosed below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:16px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Trading transactions </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">&#151;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:16px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>Remuneration of key management personnel
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Key management of the Group are the Executive Directors and the Chief Executive&#146;s Committee. Short-term employee benefits expense relating to
these individuals was &pound;14&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;9 million), post retirement benefits expense was &pound;2&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;3 million), termination benefits expense was &pound;nil (2008: &pound;6 million) and share-based payments
expense was &pound;7&nbsp;million (2008: &pound;8 million). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:16px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>38. Foreign currency translation </B></FONT></P>

2009, the date of disposal of Australia Beverages was 2.09. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The exchange rate for US dollars on 7&nbsp;May 2008, the date of demerger, was 1.98.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:16px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>39. Events after the balance sheet date </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">On
7&nbsp;September 2009 Kraft Foods, Inc. (&#147;Kraft&#148;) announced its intention to purchase the entire issued share capital of the Company. The Board of Cadbury agreed to recommend Kraft&#146;s increased Final Offer for the Company on
19&nbsp;January 2010 which valued each Cadbury 10p ordinary share at 500 pence and 0.1874 new Kraft shares. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">On 2&nbsp;February 2010, Kraft Foods
declared its recommended Final Offer wholly unconditional as to acceptances and subsequently commenced the procedure under Chapter 3 of Part 28 of the 2006 Act to acquire compulsorily all of the outstanding Cadbury Shares (including any Cadbury
Shares represented by Cadbury ADSs) which it does not already hold or has not already acquired, contracted to acquire or in respect of which it has not already received valid acceptances. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Following the acquisition by Kraft, the change of control may have an impact on the measurement criteria applied to certain of the Group&#146;s assets and
liabilities, however there is no consequential impact on the financial statements for the year ended 31&nbsp;December 2009. The impact on the financial statements in the year ending 31&nbsp;December 2010 and beyond, if any, has not yet been
determined. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The delisting of Cadbury plc on the London and New York Stock Exchanges took effect on 8&nbsp;March 2010. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>72 </B></FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>40. Changes and proposed changes to generally accepted accounting principles </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">IFRS 3 (Revised), &#147;Business combinations&#148;, continues to apply the acquisition method to business combinations, with some significant changes. For example,
all payments to purchase a business are to be recorded at fair value at the acquisition date, with some contingent payments subsequently re-measured at fair value through income. Goodwill may be calculated based on the parent&#146;s share of net
assets or it may include goodwill related to the minority interest. All transaction costs will be expensed. The standard is applicable to business combinations occurring in accounting periods beginning on or after 1&nbsp;July 2009, with earlier
application permitted. This may impact the Group should the Group make material acquisitions in the future. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">IFRS 9, &#147;Financial Instruments&#148;
replacement of IAS 39, establishes the principles for recognising and measuring financial assets, financial liabilities and some contracts to buy or sell non-financial items. This replacement standard is effective for accounting periods beginning on
or after 1&nbsp;January 2013 and has not yet been endorsed by the EU. The Group is currently assessing the impact of this revision on the Group&#146;s financial position, results of operations and cash flows. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">IAS 27 (Revised), &#147;Consolidated and separate financial statements&#148;, requires the effects of all transactions with non-controlling interests to be
recorded in equity if there is no change in control. They will no longer result in goodwill or gains and losses. The standard also specifies the accounting when control is lost. Any remaining interest in the entity is re-measured to fair value and a
gain or loss is recognised in profit or loss. This revised standard is effective for accounting periods beginning on or after 1&nbsp;July 2009. The Group is currently assessing the impact of this revision on the Group&#146;s financial position,
results of operations and cash flows. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">An amendment to IAS 39, &#147;Financial Instruments: recognition and measurement&#148;, makes two significant
changes. It prohibits designating inflation as a hedgeable component of a fixed rate debt. It also prohibits including time value in the one-sided hedged risk when designating options as hedges. The amendment is effective for annual periods
beginning on or after 1&nbsp;July 2009. The Group does not currently expect this amendment to have a material impact on the financial position, results or cash flow. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">IFRIC 17, &#147;Distributions of non cash assets to owners&#148;, clarifies how an entity should measure distributions of assets, other than cash, when it pays
dividends to its owners. The interpretation states that 1) a dividend payable should be recognised when appropriately authorised; 2) it should be measured at the fair value of the net assets to be distributed; and 3) the difference between the fair
value of the dividend paid and the carrying amount of the net assets distributed should be recognised in profit or loss. The Group is currently assessing the impact of this revision on the Group&#146;s financial position, results of operations and
cash flows. This interpretation is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1&nbsp;July 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">IFRIC 18, &#147;Transfer of assets from
customers&#148;, clarifies the accounting for arrangements where an item of property, plant and equipment, which is provided by the customer, is used to provide an ongoing service. The interpretation applies prospectively to transfers of assets from
customers received on or after 1&nbsp;July 2009, although some limited retrospective application is permitted. The Group is currently assessing the impact of this revision on the Group&#146;s financial position, results of operations and cash flows.
This interpretation is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1&nbsp;July 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Cadbury Report &amp; Accounts 2009 </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>73 </B></FONT></P>
